title-group.article-title: Background, Personal, and Environmental Influences on the Career Planning of Adolescent Girls

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Alexandra Novakovic, PhD, is an assistant professor in the department of counseling and special education at DePaul University. Her research interests include women’s career development and counselor education. She is currently researching school counselors’ experiences working with undocumented students. As a psychologist, she enjoys working with adolescents and adults in private practice. She enjoys boating, swimming, and running.

Nadya A. Fouad, PhD, is a distinguished professor and Chair of the Department of Educational Psychology at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee and faculty member in the Counseling Psychology program. She is the editor of The Counseling Psychologist. She has published articles and chapters on cross-cultural vocational assessment, career development of women and racial/ethnic minorities, interest measurement, cross-cultural counseling and race and ethnicity. She is currently working on studies to examine the persistence of women in engineering careers. She served as co-chair (with Patricia Arredondo) of the writing team for the Multicultural Guidelines on Education, Training, Practice, Research and Organizational Change, which were approved by the American Psychological Association in August, 2002 and published in the American Psychologist in May, 2003. She is an avid gardener.

abstract.p: This study investigated the influence of background variables (age, race/ethnicity, mother’s work status outside of the home, and socioeconomic status), personal variables (anticipatory role conflict and academic self-efficacy), and environmental variables (parental attachment and parental support) on aspects of adolescent girls’ career planning. Four hierarchical regression analyses were performed with a sample of 217 adolescent females in an urban high school. The dependent variables representing aspects of future career planning were (a) plans for the integration of work and family; (b) gender-traditionality of career choice; (c) career commitment; and (d) aspired education level. Personal variables made the greatest contribution to adolescent girls’ plans for the integration of work and family and career commitment. Background variables contributed most to gender-traditionality of career choice and aspired education level. Environmental variables did not make significant contributions to any of the dependent variables. Results and implications for counselors and educators are discussed.

body.p: Over the past three decades, the number of women participating in the workforce has climbed steadily. In addition, women with children are much more likely to be employed than ever before (Bureau of Labor Statistics, 2008). Despite the increase in the number of women working outside the home, considerable gender differences remain in the types of careers women choose. Traditionally female occupations continue to be overwhelmingly dominated by women, and these occupations tend to be less well paid than traditionally male occupations (Betz, 2004).

With consistent growth in the numbers of women participating in the workforce, the necessity for research addressing issues salient to women’s career development has increased substantially. At present, the body of literature pertaining to women’s career development identifies many variables that play an important role in the career development of women. Age, race/ethnicity, mother’s employment background, socioeconomic status (SES), anticipatory role conflict, academic self-efficacy, parental attachment, and parental support are variables that are often explored in the literature. Despite this information, there is still a lack of clarity about which factors are the most salient. An understanding of the most important factors influencing women’s career development will assist the development of appropriate interventions aimed at helping women reach their full educational and career potential.

sec.title: Adolescent Career Development
sec.p: Beginning at the onset of puberty, adolescence is considered the time period in which children develop both mentally and physically into adults. Not surprisingly, research in the area of career development is often focused on the adolescent years, as it is a crucial time for career decisions to be made. Adolescence is an especially important time for the study of women’s career development because adolescent girls may make career decisions that are influenced by gender stereotypes and experiences of discrimination in the educational setting. Decisions made during adolescence can profoundly impact women’s career trajectories.

sec.title: Model of Career Achievement Motivation for Women and Men
sec.p: This study attempts to organize many of the factors that influence the career planning of adolescent girls and clarify which variables emerge as the most prominent. The study was informed by the model of career achievement motivation for women and men (Farmer, 1997), which emphasizes the concept of agency, or the ability of an individual to shape his or her own career development. Farmer’s model also focuses on sex role socialization processes and their effects on beliefs, attitudes, and self-concepts, which in turn, affect motivation. The model of career achievement motivation for women and men draws heavily from social learning theory (Bandura, 1978) and emphasizes the roles of background, personal, and environmental factors on the career achievement motivation of women and men (Farmer, 1985). Background influences are established characteristics that are beyond the control of an individual such as age, gender, and ethnicity. Personal variables are related to an individual’s self-concept such as attitudes and beliefs. Environmental variables are societal or other interpersonal factors that affect an individual (Farmer, 1985). In an earlier version of the model, career and achievement motivation were explored through three dimensions: aspiration, mastery, and career motivation. Aspiration is described as the level of education and occupation to which a person aspires. Mastery is the tendency for people to choose to perform more difficult tasks and to keep struggling to master tasks once they have been started. Career motivation is the extent to which a person views involvement in a career as central to his or her adult life role (Farmer, 1985). Farmer later added a behavior variable to account for the choices women made in terms of level of education attained, occupations chosen, marital status, and number of children. She noted that researchers might change the variables of interest in the model (Farmer, 1997). In that spirit, Farmer’s model provides an excellent framework for exploring background, personal, and environmental influences on career development and identifying the most salient factors in adolescent girls’ career planning.

sec.title: Current Study
sec.p: In this study, the influence of background, personal, and environmental variable sets on aspects of adolescent girls’ career planning was explored. The background variables were comprised of age, race/ethnicity, mother’s work status outside of the home, and SES. The personal variables included anticipatory role conflict and academic self-efficacy. The environmental variables were parental attachment and parental support. The dependent variables in the model represented aspects of adolescent girls’ future career planning. The future career planning variables included: (a) plans for the integration of work and family; (b) gender traditionality of career choice; (c) aspired education level, and (d) career commitment. These variables represent common themes surrounding research on women’s career development including conflict between and management of work and family roles, discrimination experienced by women in work and school settings, and the tendency for women to underutilize their talents and abilities (Betz & Fitzgerald, 1987; Fassinger & O’Brien, 2000).

The background, personal influence, and environmental variables included in this analysis were also selected based on their prevalence in the literature on women’s career development. The following section includes an overview of research related to each variable.

sec.title: Background Variables
sec.p: Racial/ethnic background often plays a role in women’s career development within the context of barriers to career development. Leung (1995) noted that barriers, as a result of racial discrimination, limit the occupational opportunities available to members of minority groups and can restrict both actual and perceived career options for individuals.

Research has also yielded evidence of perceived barriers to the career development of ethnic minorities. Studies show that ethnic minority students perceive more career and education related barriers than the European American students (Fouad & Byars-Winston, 2005; Luzzo & McWhirter, 2001; McWhirter, 1997; McWhirter, Torres, Salgado, & Valdez, 2007). In a study of specific barriers perceived by college students, personal finances were most frequently cited as barriers among African American, Native American, and Latino/Latina American college students while time management was the most frequently cited barrier among Asian American and European American students (Perrone, Sedlacek, & Alexander, 2001).

Similar to literature on the role of racial/ethnic background in career development, research exploring SES has also been conducted within the context of barriers to educational and career attainment. A qualitative study of students from both low and high socioeconomic backgrounds showed that students of low socioeconomic background expressed barriers to the school-to-work transition as more severe and frequent than those experienced by the students of higher socioeconomic background (Blustein et al., 2002). McWhirter, Hackett, and Bandolos (1998) found that Mexican-American girls from a lower socioeconomic background perceived less parental support and interest in their academic work. Also, SES was found to play more of a role in educational choice for women than for men (Trusty, Robinson, Plata, & Ng, 2000).

Another area of research in women’s career development is the influence of various characteristics of mothers in relation to their daughters’ career development. Mothers’ characteristics such as education, employment, and gender role attitudes contributed to adolescent’s gender role attitudes regarding work (Rainey & Borders, 1997). Bohannon and Blanton (1999) found that there were no significant differences between mothers and daughters in attitudes with regard to the three variables of marriage, children, and careers.

sec.title: Personal Influence Variables
sec.p: With the majority of women with children now working outside of the home, the concept of role conflict has become a leading issue in the literature related to women’s career development (e.g. Ciabattari, 2007; Day & Chamberlain, 2005; Perrone, Webb, & Blalock, 2005). Role conflict stems from the difficulties women experience managing work and family roles. It can affect the career choices and trajectories of women as some may lower their career aspirations in order to maintain both homemaking and career roles. In a longitudinal study, Hoffnung (2004) found that women with children had significantly fewer advanced degrees and lower career status than women without children.

There is also evidence that the perception of future role conflict affects the career trajectories of women. A negative correlation was found between work and family commitment among women (Friedman & Weisbrod, 2005). Also, women who planned for role sharing marriages were significantly more likely than women in conventional marriages to be committed to careers outside the home (Hallett & Gilbert, 1997).

Bandura’s (1977) concept of self-efficacy is frequently explored in research related to career development, and it has been established as an important variable in women’s career development. Self-efficacy refers to individuals’ beliefs about their own capabilities and is acquired through four types of learning experiences: personal performance accomplishments, vicarious learning, social persuasion, and physiological and affective states (Bandura, 1997).

Self-efficacy is considered to be a domain or task-specific concept (Bandura, 1997). In women’s career development, self-efficacy for math and science is often hypothesized to influence women’s aspirations for math and science related careers (e.g. Fouad & Smith, 1996; Mau, 2003; Nauta, Epperson, & Kahn, 1998; Schaefers, Epperson, & Nauta, 1997).

Studies have also been conducted measuring self-efficacy for academic behaviors (Gore, 2006) in relation to career development. Academic self-efficacy refers to a person’s perceived ability to successfully perform academic tasks (e.g., study for a test, seek help from a teacher, taking a test) (Schunk, 1991). Academic self-efficacy was found to be predictive of both career and academic outcome expectations (Wettersten, Guilmino, & Herrick, 2005) and significantly related to academic performance in first-year college students (Chemers, Hu, & Garcia, 2001).

sec.title: Environmental Variables
sec.p: Parental attachment is a concept that has been explored with numerous outcome variables related to career development and the career development of women. Attachment has been defined as an “enduring affectional bond of substantial intensity” (Armsden & Greenberg, 1987, p. 428). Higher levels of parental attachment were associated with greater levels of self-efficacy and environmental exploration (Ketterson & Blustein, 1997). Parental attachment was also shown to have a significant and direct effect on career self-efficacy, which directly influenced career aspiration (O’Brien, Friedman, Tipton, & Linn, 2000). High school adolescent women who experienced a moderate degree of attachment to their mothers exhibited strong levels of career orientation, realism and career self-efficacy beliefs (O’Brien, 1996). Rainey and Borders (1997) found that the relationship between mother and daughter influenced early adolescent girls’ career aspirations.

Research has also substantiated the role of parental support in career development. In a meta-analysis on family variables that influence adolescents’ career expectations and aspirations, Keller and Whiston (2004) revealed that relational factors such as parental support positively influenced the career aspirations of adolescents. Perceived parental support has also been found to significantly predict vocational interests, perceived career value, career efficacy expectations (Lapan, Hinkelman, Adams, & Turner, 1999), and career task-related confidence (Turner & Lapan, 2002). Higher maternal support was associated with greater career commitment while paternal support was positively linked to career expectations and educational plans (McWhirter, Hackett, & Bandolos, 1998). Alliman-Brisett, Turner, and Skovholt (2004) found that parental support represented 40% of the variance in girls’ self-knowledge concerning educational and career endeavors. Furthermore, emotional support from parents also predicted 38% of their career decision outcome expectations. These findings were corroborated in a study revealing a strong relationship between perceived parental support and career certainty (Constantine, Wallace, & Kindaichi, 2005).

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The participants included 217 adolescent female high school students from a private, all-girls Catholic high school, in a large urban Midwestern city. The response rate for the study was approximately 72%. Participants’ ages ranged from 14 to 19, (M = 16.16, SD = 1.22). Eight percent (n =18) of the students in the sample were 14 years old, 24% (n = 52) were 15 years old, 29% (n = 62) were 16 years old, 23% (n = 50) were 17 years old, 15% (n = 32) were 18 years old, and 1% (n = 3) were 19 years old. SES was measured by students’ participation in the free or reduced lunch program. Sixty-one percent (n = 132) of the students participated in the program, 32% (n = 69) did not participate, and 7% (n = 16) did not respond to the question. To assess racial/ethnic background, students were asked to select all of the categories with which they identify: African American, Asian, European American, Latina, Middle Eastern, Native American, and Other. The categories were based on the researcher’s prior knowledge of the school population. Two students selected Other, one indicating Polish American and the other Irish American. They were added to the European American group and Other was removed from the analysis. Students who selected more than one category were coded as multiracial. Twenty-four percent (n = 52) of participants identified as African American, 3% (n = 6) as Asian, 17% (n = 37) as European American, 35% (n = 75) as Latina, 6% (n = 13) as Middle Eastern, 0.5% (n = 1) as Native American, and 15% (n = 33) as Multiracial.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Students who returned a consent form signed by a parent or guardian participated in the study. The data collection took place over a period of 2 days due to the length of the surveys. Teachers distributed the surveys to the students during their homeroom classes and instructed students to complete the first half of the surveys on the first day, and the remaining questions on the following day. Students were asked to read and sign the assent form before completing the first eight pages (Part I) of the study. They were also asked to print their names on the top of the assent form so that their survey packets could be collected by the homeroom teacher and returned to them on the second day of data collection. After the students completed the first part of the survey, the homeroom teachers collected the packets and stored them in their classrooms until the next day.

During the second day of data collection, the teachers returned the packets to the students and the students were instructed to complete the last seven pages (Part II) of the survey. After finishing Part II, the students were asked to detach the assent form and hand it to the teacher who placed it in an envelope. The surveys were then collected and kept separate from the assent forms. After the homeroom period, the homeroom teachers returned the surveys and envelope with assent forms to the researcher.

For the study, the principal extended the normally 20-min homeroom periods to 40 min each. All of the participants were able to complete the surveys during the allotted time. Students whose parents did not sign the consent form were instructed to read or do homework while others completed the surveys.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Four indicators representing background variables were assessed through a demographic information questionnaire. Students indicated their age, participation in free or reduced lunch program (SES), and whether or not their mothers were employed outside the home. Racial/ethnic background was indicated by a self-report of association with any of seven racial/ethnic group categories: African American, Asian, European American, Latina, Middle Eastern, Native American, and Other. A categorical variable, Race/Ethnicity, was created for the analysis and coded as follows: 1 = African American, 2 = Asian, 3 = European American, 4 = Latina, 5 = Middle Eastern, 6 = Native American, and 7 = Multiracial.

sec.title: Personal influence
sec.p: Two indicators were used to measure personal influence on career planning. The Attitudes Toward Multiple Role Planning scale (ATMRP; Weitzman & Fitzgerald, 1996) contains four scales (10 items per scale) scored on a 5-point Likert-type scale. Higher scores on the scales represent a more attentive approach to planning for multiple roles. The first scale, Knowledge/Certainty, relates to women’s perceptions of their knowledge about multiple role planning, and certainty of their ability to realistically plan for multiple roles. A sample item is: “I don’t know how to plan for combining my career and my family.” The second scale, Commitment to Multiple Roles, explores the commitment to a lifestyle that includes multiple roles and one’s ability to manage it effectively. A sample item is: “When it comes to work and family, there’s no reason why women ‘can’t have it all’ if they just try hard enough.” The third scale, Independence, examines self-reliance in making decisions about multiple role planning. A sample item is: “Choosing how to best manage my career and my family is something I have to do on my own and nobody can tell me how to do it.” The fourth scale, Involvement, is the perceived immediacy of the need to plan for multiple roles. A sample item is: “I seem to spend a lot of time these days thinking about how I will combine my family and my work responsibilities.” Internal consistency estimates for each of the scales ranged from .79 to .84 on the overall validation sample. On a sample of high school students, the estimates ranged from .76 to .81 (Weitzman & Fitzgerald, 1996). For the current study, the overall reliability was estimated at .79.

Validity for the ATMRP was assessed on the hypothesized developmental nature of multiple role planning by comparing total scale scores across groups. As expected, the scale score increased along with developmental level of the groups measured (High School, Undergraduate, and Graduate; Weitzman & Fitzgerald, 1996).

The second indicator, the High School Academic Self-Efficacy Inventory (Solberg, 1999), measures confidence in performing tasks associated with success in high school. It consists of 22 items on two subscales, class self-confidence and social self-confidence. Each item follows the same prompt: “How confident are you that you could successfully complete the following tasks” and is scored on an 8-point scale ranging from 0 (totally unconfident) to 7 (totally confident). A sample item is: “Take good notes in class.” The coefficient α estimate for an ethnically diverse sample of high school freshman and sophomores was .92 (Close & Solberg, 2008). For the current study, the overall reliability estimate was .89.

Solberg et al. determined construct validity for the High School Academic Self-Efficacy Inventory using principal components analysis and yielded a two-factor solution. The first factor (Class Self-Confidence) included 8 items related to academics with loadings ranging from .80 to .58. The second factor (Social Self-Confidence) consisted of 8 items related to social situations and included factor loadings ranging from .70 to .51 (as cited in Close & Solberg, 2008).

sec.title: Environment
sec.p: Two indicators assessed environmental influence on career planning. The Inventory of Parent and Peer Attachment (IPPA; Armsden & Greenberg, 1987) measures adolescent attachment with their parents and peers. It contains two scales, parent attachment and peer attachment, of 60 items measured on a 5-point Likert-type scale (1 = almost never or never, 2 = seldom, 3 = sometimes, 4 = often, and 5 = almost always or always). The peer attachment scale was not used in the study since it was not a variable of interest. The quality of the attachment relationship was determined by the degree of trust and communication relative to alienation. The parent attachment score for each individual was determined by the sum of the trust and communication subscale scores minus the sum of the alienation subscale score. The parent attachment scale contains the following subscales: (a) trust (10 items) including “My parents trust my judgment,” (b) communication (10 items) including “My parents encourage me to talk about my difficulties,” and (c) alienation (8 items) including “My parents don’t understand what I’m going through these days.” Reliability coefficients on a sample of university undergraduate students ranged from coefficient α = .86 to .91 (Armsden & Greenberg, 1987). For the current study, reliability coefficients ranged from .62 to .86.
Convergent validity for the IPPA was determined through significant correlations with measures of well-being and family climate (Armsden & Greenberg, 1987).

The Career-Related Parent Support scale (CRPSS; Turner, Alliman-Brisett, Lapan, Udipi, & Ergun, 2003) measures parental support for educational and vocational development. It contains four subscales that are scored on a 5-point Likert-type scale (1 = strongly disagree to 5 = strongly agree). The instrumental assistance subscale contains 7 items and reflects parents’ support of their adolescent’s career-related skill development. A sample item is: “My parents teach me things that I will someday be able to use at my job.” The second subscale, career-related modeling contains 7 items and reflects parents’ career-related modeling behavior. A sample item is: “My parents tell me about things that happen to them at work.” The third subscale, verbal encouragement, contains 6 items and demonstrates parents’ praise and encouragement associated with their adolescents’ career and educational development. A sample item is: “My parents encourage me to go to a technical school or college after I graduate.” The fourth subscale, emotional support, contains 7 items and reflects parents’ support of the affect experienced by adolescent in relationship to their career and educational development. A sample item is: “My parents talk to me when I am worried about my future career.” Turner et al. (2003) reported an overall reliability of coefficient α = .92 in a diverse sample of disadvantaged or at-risk middle school adolescents. The internal consistency estimates for the scores across the four subscales ranged from .78 to .85, and the 2-week test–retest reliability estimate for the total score was r = .79. For the present study, the overall reliability was estimated at coefficient α = .93.
Construct validity for the CRPSS was demonstrated through moderate correlations of the subscales with measures career decision making self-efficacy and outcome expectations (Turner et al., 2003).

sec.title: Future career planning
sec.p: Plans for the integration of work and family were measured using The Orientation to Occupational-Family Integration scale (OOFI; Gilbert, Dancer, Rossman, & Thorn 1991). The OOFI measures the perceptions of work and family involvement in both men and women. It consists of three scales, each of which reflects a different type of orientation (female traditional, male traditional, and atraditional). Two of the three scales were used in this analysis. The female traditional scale reflects the view that women are responsible for housework and childcare, and men are responsible for providing for the family. A sample item is: “After marriage, I see my spouse as working full-time and being the major financial provider.” The atraditional scale, reflects an integration of occupational and family roles by both partners in a marriage. A sample item is: “ I see my spouse and I both working full-time and sharing the financial responsibility continuously throughout our marriage.” The scales are measured using a 5-point Likert-type scale to answer how much a person thinks about the content of each item (1 = not at all to 5 = very much) and how much a person is committed according to the content of each item (1 = not at all to 5 = very much). Scores are calculated for thought and commitment, with higher scores reflecting more thought and higher commitment to a particular work-family orientation. The scale was tested on a sample of adolescent females and reliability coefficients ranged from .87 to .94 (Gilbert, et al., 1991). For the current study, the reliability coefficients ranged from .82 to .85.

Validity for the ATMRP was assessed on the hypothesized developmental nature of multiple role planning by comparing total scale scores across groups. As expected, the scale score increased along with developmental level of the groups measured (high school, undergraduate, and graduate; Weitzman & Fitzgerald, 1996). Also, a contrasted groups procedure was used to assess criterion related validity to assess the hypothesis that the content of work-family plans is related to the process of multiple role planning. Results showed that participants with compatible work-family plans had significantly higher scaled scores than those with incompatible work–family plans.

Gender traditionality of career choice was measured by a self-report question in which participants indicated what jobs they have considered pursuing after completion of their education. The responses were coded on a 3-point scale (1 = nontraditional, 2 = neutral, or 3 = traditional) based on the percentage of women working in the particular field according to the United States Census Bureau (U.S. Census Bureau, 2006). A nontraditional career area is one in which less than 30% of the workers are women. A female traditional career area is made up of 70% or more female workers. A neutral career area consists of between 30% and 70% female workers.

Career Commitment was measured by a self-report question indicating how committed participants were to pursuing a career that would require a good deal of time and would become something they would do for a lifetime (Hallett & Gilbert, 1997). The responses were scored on a 5-point scale ranging from (1 = not at all to 5 = very much).

Aspired education level was measured by a self-report question specifying the highest level of education participants wished to pursue in the future. Their responses were recorded on a 5-point scale (1 = high school diploma, 2 = technical or vocational school degree, 3 = bachelor’s degree, 4 = master’s degree, and 5 = doctoral degree).

sec.title: Analysis of Data
sec.p: The multiple regression assumptions of linearity, normality, and homoscedasticity were examined using residuals scatterplots (Tabachnick & Fidell, 2006). The data appeared to adequately meet the assumptions. Separate hierarchical multiple regression analyses were conducted to determine which set of independent variables (background, personal, and environmental) made the greatest contribution to each of four dependent variables: (a) plans for the integration of work and family; (b) gender-traditionality of career choice; (c) aspired level of education; and (d) career commitment. The order in which the independent variable sets were entered into the regression equation was based the developmental theoretical perspective of career development (Savickas, 2002). The amount of variance accounted for in the dependent variables by each of the independent variable sets (background, personal, and environment) was determined. A regression equation with β coefficients showed the change in the dependent variables for each increment of change in an independent variable (Pedhazur, 1997). Effect sizes were measured based on Cohen’s (1992) criteria of r = .1, .3, and .5 for small, medium, and large effect sizes, respectively. A post hoc power analysis was performed using G* Power 3.1 (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009) and the results indicated that the sample size of 217 used for this study was a sufficient number of participants needed to detect an effect with an α level of .05 and a power of .95.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Means, standard deviations, and correlations of the study variables are displayed in Table 1. The first analysis examined which of the three sets of independent variables made the greatest contribution to adolescent girls’ plans for the integration of work and family. The results are presented in Table 2. The background variable set was entered first and accounted for 3.0% of the overall variance (R2 = .030). This amount was not statistically significant (p = .220). The second block of variables added (personal) accounted for an additional 4.9% of the overall variance (R2 = .078) and this change was significant (p = .008) with a medium effect size. Role conflict (B = .590, p = .002) was a significant predictor within this set of variables. The third block of variables entered (environment) accounted for an additional 1.2% of the overall variance (R2 = .090) and this change was not significant (p = .307).

fn.p: Note. AGE = age; ASP = aspired education; ATT = attitudes toward multiple role planning; CAR = career commitment; ETH = race/ethnicity; GEN = gender traditionality of career choice; MOT = mother’s employment outside of home; ORS = OFFI-role share; PAT = parental attachment; PSU = parental support; SES = socioeconomic status; SLF = self-efficacy.

caption.p: Hierarchical Set Regression Analysis for Plans for Integration of Work and Family.

tr.td: Mother’s work status outside of the home
Mother’s work status outside of the home
Mother’s work status outside of home

fn.p: Note. R2 = .030 for Group 1; ▵R2 = .049 for Group 2; ▵R2 = .012 for Group 3.

sec.p: The second analysis explored which of the three independent variables made the greatest contribution to adolescent girls’ gender-traditionality of career choice. The results are presented in Table 3. The first block of variables entered (background) accounted for 7.1% of the variance (R2 = .071) and this amount was significant (p = .007) with a medium effect size. Within this block of variables, age was a significant predictor (B = .141, p = .002). The second block of variables entered (personal) accounted for an additional 6.0% of the total variance (R2 = .132) and this change was also significant (p = .002) with a medium effect size. In this second set of variables, academic self-efficacy was a significant predictor (B = −.218, p = .001). The third block of variables (environment) accounted for an additional 1.3% (R2 = .145) and this change was not significant (p = .258).

caption.p: Hierarchical Set Regression Analysis for Gender Traditionality of Career Choice.

tr.td: Mother’s work status outside of the home
Mother’s work status outside of the home
Mother’s work status outside of home

fn.p: Note. R2 = .071 for Group 1; ▵R2 = .060 for Group 2; ▵R2 = .013 for Group 3.

sec.p: The third analysis examined which of the three independent variables made the greatest contribution to the career commitment of adolescent girls. The results are presented in Table 4. The first block of variables entered (background) accounted for 1.6% of the variance (R2 = .016) and this amount was not significant (p = .534). The second block of variables entered (personal) accounted for an additional 12.7% of the total variance (R2 = .144) and this change was significant (p = .000) with a medium to high effect size. Within this second set of variables, academic self-efficacy was a significant predictor (B = .356, p = .000). The third block of variables (environment) accounted for an additional .03% of the total variance (R2 = .147). The addition of this set of variables did not result in a significant change in the total variance (p = .697).

caption.p: Hierarchical Set Regression Analysis for Career Commitment.

tr.td: Mother’s work status outside of the home
Mother’s work status outside of the home
Mother’s work status outside of home

fn.p: Note. R2 = .016 for Group 1; ▵R2 = .127 for Group 2; ▵R2 = .003 for Group 3.

sec.p: The fourth analysis explored which of the three independent variables made the greatest contribution to adolescent girls’ aspired education level. The results are presented in Table 5. The first block of variables entered (background) accounted for 5.6% of the variance (R2 = .056) and this amount was significant (p = .028) with a medium effect size. Age was a significant predictor within this set of variables (B = −.153, p = .007). The second block of variables entered (personal) accounted for an additional 7.9% of the variance (R2 = .136) and this change was significant (p = .000) with a medium to large effect size. Within this second set of variables, academic self-efficacy was a significant predictor (B = .285, p = .000). The third block of variables (environment) accounted for an additional 1.4% of the variance (R2 = .150) and did not result in a significant change in the total variance of aspired education level (p = .229).

caption.p: Hierarchical Set Regression Analysis for Aspired Education Level.

tr.td: Mother’s work status outside of the home
Mother’s work status outside of the home
Mother’s work status outside of home

fn.p: Note. R2 = .056 for Group 1; ▵R2 = .079 for Group 2; ▵R2 = .014 for Group 3.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This purpose of the present study was to explore the contributions of three sets of variables (background, personal, or environmental) to aspects of the career planning of adolescent girls (plans for the integration of work and family, gender-traditionality of career choice, career commitment, and aspired educational level). Personal variables contributed most to adolescent girls’ plans for the integration of work and family while the influences of background and environmental variables were not significant. Within the personal variable set, the attitudes toward multiple role-planning variable was a unique independent predictor in the regression analysis. This suggests that mindfulness and planning about multiple roles leads to higher levels of commitment to a future involving both family and occupational work. The finding is consistent with previous research conducted to address the impact of planning for future multiple role involvement. Hallet and Gilbert (1997) found that women who planned for marriages in which they would share the childcare role with their spouse were more likely to be committed to a lifelong career that would require a substantial amount of their time and energy.

Background and personal variables both significantly influenced gender-traditionality of career choice, with the background variables making the greatest contribution. The contribution of the environmental variable set was not significant. Age was a significant predictor within the background set of variables. This finding suggests that as adolescent girls age, they tend to plan for more gender traditional careers. One explanation for this result is that older adolescent girls are more aware of barriers that would make attaining a nontraditional career more difficult. This awareness could be influenced by personal experience as well as suggestions from family members and educators. Research by Kenny, Blustein, Chaves, Grossman, and Gallagher (2003) demonstrated that barriers negatively predict educational and vocational attitudes. Older adolescents may also be more likely to consider childbearing in their future and think about difficulties involved in rearing children and having a career outside of the home. They may be more likely to choose traditional careers because these careers tend to be more accommodating toward women who are primary caregivers as well as work outside the home (i.e., flexible schedules, job sharing).

The academic self-efficacy variable was a significant negative predictor within the personal set of variables. This finding suggests that adolescent girls with lower academic self-efficacy endorse traditional female gender role careers more than nontraditional careers. Adolescent girls with lower academic self-efficacy may perceive themselves as unable to succeed in nontraditional careers and therefore are less likely to choose those careers. These results can be viewed as an extension of previous research demonstrating that higher math and science self-efficacy leads to a greater likelihood of success in math and science careers or traditionally male dominated careers (Betz, 2004).

Personal variables made the greatest contribution to adolescent girls’ career commitment while the contributions of both the background and environmental variables were not significant. This finding is consistent with research by Farmer (1985) who found that career commitment was influenced by personal factors nearly 3 times as much as background and environment factors combined.

The academic self-efficacy predictor variable was significant in this analysis suggesting that higher academic self-efficacy leads to greater commitment to obtaining and maintaining a career outside of the home. An interpretation for this finding is that adolescent girls who demonstrate self-efficacy for school related tasks are more likely believe that they can be successful in completing tasks required in a future career. Similar findings have been demonstrated in studies exploring math and science related self-efficacy and commitment to math and science related careers (e.g. Chemers, Zurbriggen, Syed, Goza, & Bearman, 2011; Mau, 2003).

Both the background and personal variables made significant contributions to the aspired educational level of adolescent girls with the background variable set making the greatest contribution. Within the background variable set, age was a significant and negative predictor variable. This finding suggests that younger students in the study aspired to higher education levels while older students aimed for lower levels of education. It is similar to the previous finding in this study that older students are more likely to strive for gender traditional careers. Again, an explanation for this result is that older students perceive more barriers to higher education than younger students. Younger students do not understand or do not yet anticipate any barriers to their career aspirations. Another explanation could be that the younger students have not spent enough time in high school to develop negative attitudes about education. As students attend higher grades, they are more likely to encounter difficult educational material that could cloud their view of their success and ability to achieve in education. Mau (2003) also found that the female students were less likely to persist in their science and engineering career aspirations over time and attributed this finding to institutional and cultural barriers that women face in educational and occupational arenas.

Academic self-efficacy was a significant predictor within the personal variable set. This result indicates that adolescent girls who have strong beliefs in their ability to succeed in academic tasks are more likely to aspire to higher education levels. Similar results have been shown in other research on self-efficacy and educational aspirations. Self-efficacy is associated with academic outcome expectations (Wettersten et al., 2005) and high educational aspirations for scientific, educational, literary, and medical career pursuits (Bandura, Barbaranelli, Caprara, & Pastorelli, 2001).

The environmental variables (parental attachment and parental support) did not demonstrate a significant influence on any of the dependent variables in the study. Although research shows that parental support and parental attachment do influence adolescent girls’ career development (O’Brien, 1996; Rainey & Borders, 1997), other research shows that parental variables influence self-efficacy, which in turn affects aspects of career development (Ketterson & Blustein, 1997; O’Brien, Friedman, Tipton, & Linn, 2000; Turner & Lapan, 2002). It is possible that even though parental influences were not significant in this study, they do influence adolescent girls’ career development through other variables such as self-efficacy. Additionally, it is possible that other environmental indicators besides parental interactions might demonstrate greater influence on aspects of adolescent girls’ career planning. Environmental factors such as extended family influence, teacher support, and teacher student dynamics could be explored.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: Several aspects of the sample population of this study should be noted when interpreting the results of this research study. Because of the school’s religious affiliation, the responses of the participants could have been influenced by their beliefs in the teachings of the religion and/or the views of the religion on women and the world of work. Additionally, the reading level of the participants in this study should be considered along with the study results. Participants were instructed to ask for assistance from their teacher if they did not understand a question, but some students may not have sought help and answered questions without fully understanding their meaning. Similarly, students who speak English as a second language may have experienced more difficulty reading and understanding the survey questions. This could have resulted in inaccurate responses in some of the surveys.

The self-report nature of the surveys should also be noted when interpreting the results of the study. Many factors such as participants’ moods, interactions with parents and teachers, and desire to please or retaliate against authority figures may have influenced their responses to the survey questions.

The indicators used in the background, personal, and environmental variable sets were selected based on their prominence in the career development literature. Other indicators that were not selected for the study could be shown to influence the career development of adolescent girls differently. Also, although the reliability of the measures used in the study was adequate, measurement error from the indicators used could have biased the results of the study. Future studies could employ measures with higher reliability or different measures altogether to represent the background, personal, and environmental variables.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The results of this study highlight the importance of adolescent girls’ backgrounds and personal attitudes or beliefs with regard to their career planning. Counselors and educators working with adolescent female populations should consider interventions designed to increase knowledge about planning for and managing multiple roles. Additionally, the finding that older students in this study had lower educational aspirations and more gender traditional career plans than the younger students suggests that interventions concerning the pursuit of higher education and the exploration of gender nontraditional careers should be aimed at younger adolescents. These interventions should also address barriers to career and education attainment since real and perceived barriers can inhibit adolescent girls’ planning for future careers. Finally, the results of this study demonstrated the importance of academic self-efficacy in adolescent girls’ gender traditionality of career choice, career commitment, and aspired education level. Findings about the importance of self-efficacy in women’s career development are consistently demonstrated in the literature, and they should be considered an important aspect of educational programming and interventions aimed at assisting adolescent girls in reaching their academic and career potential.
